Full-Stack Developer

Ocean Data Lab, 2022 Summer

Ocean Data Lab Website: view

My development product: view

Context

In the past, members of the Ocean Data Lab have collected over 1.5GB ocean acoustic data from large underwater networks. Various types of data visualizations are created to better analyze those data. However, Those visualizations requires different inputs such as location, time interval, graph type, etc, to be generated. It will be much convenient to manipulate these required parameters on an interface than writing Python codes.

Responsibility

Created a website where users can select different locations, graph types, and time interval to generate different data visualizations. Website also allows users to download the acoustic data in CSV file based on different requirements.

Takeaway

I chosed a tech combination (React + Flask) that I never tried before. My experience of building the interface highly improves my problem-solving skills and research skills. I got to know Professor Shima and a group of amazing researchers.

Full-stack Developer

Simoni Lab, 2022 Summer

Simoni Lab website: view

Context

The Embrace Sunshine team is building a Wechat-based mini-Program to deliver adherence intervention for people diagnosed with HIV. Furthermore, a management system to manipulate the database is also needed to be developed.

Responsibility

Assisted in building both the front-end and backend of the Embrace Sunshine Wechat Mini-program. Designed and built the front-end interface of the management websit for the Mini-program.

Takeaway

As a developer, I highly improved my ability of communicating and collaborating with the UI teams within a product development pipeline. I also sharpened my front-end programming skills as well as getting to learn new tech contents like AWS cloud storaging and serverless framework.

Employeefind

Simplify your process in finding employees

Website Url: view

Full stack web development

Developed an online human resource website for recruiters to find employees easily.

React front-end

The website is built on top of one of the most popular front-end frameworks React.js. Components are created with MaterialUI.

Mock backend

Currently, we are still working on creating the backend server to serve the need of send data to the front-end website. Thus, All the data shown on the website are now mocked by npm package axios-mock-adapter.

Modern Deployment

The front-end website is currently hosted on Netlify for viewing purpose. When the backend is ready, we will deploy on Amazon AWS EC2.

Ocean Data Lab

Visualize Hydrophone Data

My development work: view

Topic

Designed and developed a responsive website to help visualize and download hydrophone data for Ocean Data Lab led by Professor Shima Abadi

React front-end

The website is built on top of one of the most popular front-end frameworks React.js. UI components are created with MaterialUI, and map is powered by react-map-gl

Flask backend

Many scientific graphs can only be created with the help of Python libraries. Thus, I chose Flask, a micro web framework written in Python, to serve as the backend server for the website.

Modern Deployment

The interactive visualization tool is deployed on AWS EC2 for public usage

Reflection - Dev Tool Chain

This is my HCDE 438 reflection, where I reflect on my experience in the class and the projects I worked on.

Overview and Usage

Overview: I am using the p5.js library and have created a gluttonous snake game. To start playing, click the "Start Game" button and you will enter the game immediately. There is a score panel in the top left corner that displays the number of points you have earned (which corresponds to the number of red boxes the snake eats). If the snake eats itself or hits the wall (the edge of the browser window), the game is over. You can restart the game by clicking the "Start Game" button again. Enjoy the game!

Or, you can click the linked text below to view the game page. https://andrewliu66.github.io/snake-game/

Here is the github repository link: https://github.com/AndrewLiu66/snake-game

Development Process
Here's a step-by-step overview of how to build the gluttonous snake game using p5.js:
  1. Set up the basic HTML structure for the game, including a canvas element and a "Start Game" button. Also include a script tag to include the p5.js library.
  2. Define global variables for the snake, food, scale, score, and a flag to indicate whether the game has started.
  3. Create the setup function. In this function, create the canvas, create a new snake object, set the frame rate, and call the pickLocation function to create the initial location of the food.
  4. Create the draw function. In this function, set the background color, check if the game has started, update the position of the snake, check if the snake has eaten the food, check if the snake has died, and draw the snake and food on the canvas.
  5. Create the keyPressed function. In this function, set the direction of the snake based on the key that was pressed.
  6. Create the pickLocation function. In this function, generate a random location for the food.
  7. Create the restartGame function. In this function, reset the score, create a new snake object, and call the pickLocation function to create the initial location of the food. Also reset the gameStarted flag to false.
  8. Define the Snake class. In the constructor function, initialize the head of the snake at the center of the canvas. In the dir function, set the direction of the snake based on the x and y parameters. In the update function, update the position of the head and tail of the snake. In the death function, check if the snake has died by going off the screen or hitting its tail. In the eat function, check if the snake has eaten the food. In the show function, draw the snake on the canvas.
  9. Add an event listener to the "Start Game" button that calls the setup function and sets the gameStarted flag to true.
  10. Test the game and make adjustments as needed.

Here is an image of the unfinished state of the game:

Issue
During the game creation process, I encountered an issue where the snake would not stop once it hit the wall. I struggled for a bit to find a solution, but here are the steps I took to resolve the issue:
  1. I located the function that defines the end condition of the game.
  2. I modified the condition in the if statement to fix the bug.
  3. I replayed the game to ensure that it worked.
As a result of these steps, I was able to resolve the issue and make the game work.
Ideas and Future:
  • Add different difficulty levels (easy, medium, hard) to make the game more challenging.
  • Allow the player to choose the size of the game board, giving them more control over the game.
  • Implement a two-player mode, where two people can compete against each other.
Ultimately, the ideas and features I choose to add to my website should align with my goals for the site and the audience I hope to reach.
